Introduction

A breast mass is a common clinical finding that may be benign or malignant.  The approach to evaluation involves history-taking, clinical examination, imaging, and biopsy when necessary.  The appropriate evaluation is guided by a patient's age and risk factors for malignancy.  The diagnostic pathway is essential to differentiate benign conditions (eg, fibroadenoma, cysts) from breast cancer and to ensure timely and appropriate management.

Common breast masses

Benign breast masses



  • Fibroadenoma:  Benign solid tumor composed of glandular and fibrous tissue.  Fibroadenomas typically cause a painless and mobile rubbery mass that are hormonally mediated (ie, increased size with elevated estrogen levels).
  • Breast cyst:  Fluid-filled round mass that may fluctuate in size due to cyclic hormonal changes.  Cysts may be painless or become painful, especially in the days leading up to the onset of menses.
  • Fibrocystic breast disease:  The development of fibrous tissue and cysts within the breast, often associated with hormonal fluctuations.  It may cause cyclical breast pain and breast "lumpiness."  Breast examination may show an isolated mass, scattered masses, or irregular densities.
  • Galactocele (
    figure 1
    ):  A complication of lactation that occurs when the mammary duct becomes obstructed due to inflammation or trauma, leading to a dilated cystic area filled with breast milk that is palpable as a soft breast mass.
  • Breast abscess (
    image 1
    ):  A localized collection of pus in the breast tissue that can develop spontaneously or as a complication of lactational mastitis and cause a fluctuant, tender breast mass.
  • Fat necrosis:  Mechanical trauma or surgery may lead to localized ischemia to an area of breast tissue, resulting in necrosis of adipose cells and subsequent inflammation and fibrotic scarring that causes a firm, irregulat breast mass.

Malignant breast masses



  • Invasive ductal carcinoma:  The most common malignant cause of a breast mass.  Malignant cells originate from the ductal epithelium and invade surrounding breast tissue, inducing a fibrotic response and causing a firm, irregular mass.  The precursor to invasive ductal carcinoma, ductal carcinoma in situ, is usually too small to cause a palpable mass.
  • Invasive lobular carcinoma:  Malignant cells arise from the lobules of the breast and invade the surrounding breast tissue in a single-file or individual fashion.  These tumors often present with diffuse growth and the resulting mass may not be well-defined.
  • Paget disease of the breast (
    figure 2
    ):  A rare type of breast malignancy that causes a scaly or ulcerated lesion of the nipple and areola and often has an underlying breast mass.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer (
    figure 3
    ):  An aggressive malignancy that presents with changes to the appearance of the breast (eg, swelling, erythema, peau d'orange) that may be accompanied by a palpable breast mass.

Clinical presentation



Patients have a palpable breast mass (lump), which may be detected incidentally by the patient or during a physical examination.  Pain or tenderness is more common in benign conditions, but can be associated with malignancy and may fluctuate with estrogen level changes during the menstrual cycle.



Some breast masses can cause nipple discharge, which may be clear, milky, bloody, or purulent, depending on the underlying cause.  Skin changes, including dimpling, retraction, or ulceration, are suspicious for malignancy (particularly inflammatory breast cancer).  In some cases, axillary lymphadenopathy may be present, which could indicate malignancy or an inflammatory process such as mastitis.

Diagnostic evaluation

Step 1: Clinical assessment



The evaluation of a breast mass begins with a history and physical examination.  History should focus on:



  • Onset, duration, and progression of the mass.
  • Associated symptoms (eg, pain, nipple discharge, skin changes) and any relation to the menstrual cycle.
  • Reproductive history (eg, menstrual history, pregnancy, lactation, use of hormonal medications).
  • Family history of malignancy.


Physical examination includes:



  • Inspection:  Assess for asymmetry, skin changes, nipple abnormalities, or signs of trauma.
  • Palpation:  Helps determine the size, shape, consistency, mobility, and tenderness of the mass.  A firm, fixed, irregular mass raises suspicion for malignancy, whereas a smooth, mobile, well-defined mass is more suggestive of a benign condition.
  • Evaluation of lymph nodes:  Axillary and supraclavicular lymph nodes should also be assessed, noting any enlargement, matting, or fixation.

Step 2: Imaging studies



Various imaging modalities may be used to evaluate a breast mass:



  • Mammography:  In patients with a breast mass, diagnostic mammography is performed instead of screening mammography.  A diagnostic study provides more views of the breast than screening mammography and allows for additional techniques (eg, spot compression) and angles to evaluate suspicious areas.  Findings suggestive of malignancy include microcalcifications (
    image 2
    ), mass lesions with spiculated or irregular borders (
    image 3
    ), architectural distortion, and asymmetry.
  • Ultrasonography:  Used alone or in conjunction with mammography to further characterize breast masses.  Ultrasonography often provides evaluation of benign lesions like breast cysts (appear as well-defined anechoic lesions with posterior acoustic enhancement) (
    image 4
    ) and fibroadenomas (uniformly hypoechogenic round mass) (
    image 5
    ).
  • MRI:  Used occasionally to obtain further information when mammographic or sonographic findings are equivocal.


The choice of imaging depends on the patient's age, clinical findings, and degree of suspicion for cancer (

figure 4
):



  • Age <30:  Breast ultrasonography is usually the first-line study because younger patients tend to have higher breast density (limiting visualization of some masses on mammography) and lower risk for malignancy.
  • Age 30-40:  Either mammography or breast ultrasonography may be the first-line study depending on patient factors and suspected diagnosis.  Often both are performed because the studies are complementary.  In this age group, ultrasonography has higher sensitivity for malignancy than mammography.
  • Age â‰¥40:  Mammography is the first-line study; however, ultrasonography is often also performed for further information.


Following an imaging study, the Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) is used to determine a standardized score to stratify the risk for malignancy and guide the need for biopsy or surgical resection.  The scoring system is as follows:



  • 0:  Needs additional evaluation
  • 1:  Normal findings
  • 2:  Benign lesion
  • 3:  Probably benign lesion (malignancy risk <2%)
  • 4:  Suspicious for malignancy (broad category with malignancy risk between 2% and 95%)
  • 5:  High risk for malignancy (malignancy risk 95%-100%)
  • 6:  Biopsy-proven malignancy


All scores of 0, 4, or 5 require additional intervention with further imaging studies, close imaging follow-up, or biopsy.

Step 3: Tissue diagnosis



Biopsy should be performed in patients with suspicious imaging findings or in those with a clinically suspicious breast mass, even if imaging findings are normal (discordance).  Patients with a benign finding can be offered biopsy or follow-up imaging in 6 months.



  • Core needle biopsy (
    figure 5
    ):  The preferred method of biopsy because it extracts a "core" sample of breast tissue.  It is usually performed under imaging guidance to directly target the abnormal area for sampling.
  • Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) (
    figure 6
    ):  Inferior to core needle biopsy for evaluation of breast masses because it does not maintain tissue architecture (ie, cannot distinguish between invasive and in situ carcinoma) and has a higher false-negative rate.  It is most often used for cyst aspiration and to evaluate for lymph node metastases in patients with cancer.
  • Excisional biopsy:  Involves complete removal of a breast mass for diagnosis.  It is usually performed when core needle biopsy is inconclusive or inconsistent with imaging findings or if a core needle biopsy is not technically feasible.

Management



Benign conditions such as fibroadenomas, fat necrosis, and simple cysts can often be managed conservatively with observation.  Symptomatic cysts and galactoceles may be aspirated, whereas enlarging or symptomatic fibroadenomas may require surgical excision.  Abscesses are treated with antibiotics and either needle aspiration or surgical drainage.  Pain related to benign masses can typically be managed with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.



Malignant breast masses require a multidisciplinary approach that may involve surgery (lumpectomy or mastectomy), radiation, chemotherapy, or endocrine therapy depending on tumor characteristics.

Prognosis and prevention



The prognosis of a breast mass depends on its etiology.  Benign breast conditions generally have an excellent prognosis.  However, some benign conditions (eg, atypical ductal hyperplasia, atypical lobular hyperplasia, radial scar, sclerosing adenosis, complex fibroadenoma) may have a slightly increased risk for future malignancy.  Early-stage breast cancer has a high survival rate when treated appropriately, whereas advanced disease carries a poorer prognosis.



Breast cancer screening plays a crucial role in early detection and improving outcomes.  Routine mammography is recommended every 1-2 years for women beginning at age 40-50 depending on patient risk factors and preferences.  Women at high risk (eg, BRCA mutations, strong family history) should begin screening at an earlier age and may be offered screening breast MRI in addition to mammography.  Screening beyond age 75 is appropriate for some patients based on life expectancy and overall health status.

Summary



Both benign and malignant breast conditions are common causes of breast masses.  The evaluation of a breast mass involves a systematic approach to distinguish between these conditions, including physical examination, imaging, and possible biopsy.  Imaging may involve mammography, ultrasonography, or a combination of both to risk-stratify the masses to determine if biopsy is indicated.
